question:
Title: Opportunities in American Sign Language (ASL) Interpreting in Ontario

Body:

The demand for American Sign Language (ASL)-English interpreters in Ontario is high due to the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA), which was introduced in 2005 and mandates accessibility standards for all levels of government and private and public sector businesses. This demand exceeds the current supply, creating opportunities for those trained in ASL interpreting.

Interpreting work can take place anywhere clients need to go, such as hospitals, banks, lawyer offices, conferences, and classes. Graduates are often self-employed and serve consumers of all ages. Knowledge of ASL and Deaf culture opens up doors for communication in any career and workplace.

Partnerships with organizations embedded in the Deaf and deafblind communities provide field placement experiences, employment opportunities, and support ongoing development of programs. If you're interested in learning more about this program or signing up for college news and updates, please contact Zeenat Janmohamed, Chair, School of Deaf and Deafblind Studies.

Contact Information:
- Phone number: 416-415-2000
- TTY number: 1-877-515-5559
- Email address: ask.george@georgebrown.ca
- Social Media Hub available for more information.

Additionally, it is important to acknowledge the traditional territories of the Indigenous peoples on whose lands we live and work. If you're interested in learning more about land acknowledgment, please contact us as well.

Join our community to explore the opportunities in American Sign Language interpreting and make a difference in people's lives.?
